Award.AwardTitle: Understanding How Motile Cells Make Decisions When Subject to Multiple Chemical and Physical Cues

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells make behavioral decisions based on measurements of their environment all the time. Chemical cues re-orient cells towards food or sites of infection. Physical cues report on local hydrostatic pressure, cellular crowding, adhesion etc. Together these cues allow a cell to make decisions about its fate (if it is in an embryonic state), move, divide, assemble into a tissue etc. Understanding how cells integrate multiple physico-chemical measurements before making a decision is thus critical in characterizing tissue and organ development, wound healing, cancer metastasis and in controlling cells to create artificial tissues and organs. This award supports research that will combine experimental and theoretical studies to study how a single cell can integrate physical and chemical cues to decide which direction to move in. Since all natural and artificial tissues contain cells, understanding how they make decisions will allow for better control of natural tissues and provide guidelines for creating artificial functional tissues. Thus this research will help society. Furthermore, as the research is highly multi-disciplinary and involves tools and techniques from molecular biology, microscopy, microfluidics on the one hand, and statistical and nonlinear physics, hydrodynamics, and optimization and control theory on the other, it will broaden participation of engineers and scientists from many different group including under-represented minorities and positively impact engineering education by fertilizing different disciplines.

Oriented motility of cells in response to external cues is critical in determining the survival of single-celled organisms and the normal development and maintenance of multi-cellular organisms like us. The molecular basis for this orientation has been widely studied but an integrated quantitative model remains elusive, in part due to the absence of controlled quantitative environments. This award will support research to close the gap. Microenvironments that can be programmed with both chemical and physical cues will force neutrophils to crawl through channels they occlude and provide high-resolution images of intracellular signaling for automated data analysis. The ability to quantitatively control the cellular environment and simultaneously measure intracellular signaling will allow for a multi-phase model of cell polarization and motility that accounts for cytoskeletal and membrane dynamics combining statistical mechanics, hydrodynamics and elasticity, while integrating the sensing of the physical (pressure) and chemical (cytokine) environment into a biophysical basis for cellular decision making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

 

Oriented motility of cells in chemical gradients, or chemotaxis, plays a critical role in survival for single-celled organisms and development and immune function in metazoans. The molecules underlying orientation have been widely studied but an integrated quantitative model remains elusive, in part due to the absence of controlled quantitative environments.  The study proposes to use a combination of experimental and theoretical studies to study how a single cell can integrate physical and chemical cues to come to a decision about which direction to move in a confined geometry implemented using a microfluidic device.  Decision making at the cellular scale needs to integrate chemical and physical cues that are converted to modes of cellular polarization and cytoskeletal dynamics that are converted to motion eventually. The study proposed to create a quantitative experimental system to understand how a single cell can be stimulated using dynamic physical and chemical environments, and then create an integrative mathematical and computational framework to understand the observations.  

 

Results

 

Using microfluidic devices that were custom-built, the researchers showed how cells integrate multiple measurement modalities to navigate their environment. Soluble and substrate-bound chemical gradients and physical cues such as pressure have all been shown to influence cell orientation and migration.  In particular, when cells were confined in microchannels and forced to make a decision about which fork to take at a bifurcation, they identified and chose a path of lower hydraulic resistance in the absence of chemical cues.  Moreover, the response to the physical asymmetry was able to override a dynamically generated chemical cue. Motile cells may use this bias as a result of hydraulic resistance, barotaxis,  in concert with chemotaxis to navigate complex environments. Additionally, the observations showed a directional memory in chemotactic neutrophil-like cells. This directional memory was manifest as a long-lived intracellular asymmetry, in long-lived polarized cytoskeletal memories, that decays slower than observed membrane phospholipid signaling.  The researchers built mathematical models to characterize the long-term memory in the system, consistent with experiments. They then generalized the model to account for how a cell makes decisions when confronted with both physical and chemical cues that may work antagonistically or together, drawing on a connection to a classic psychological paradigm, the two-alternative forced choice test, but now in a cellular context.

 

Broader Impact

Cells make behavioral decisions based on measurements of their environment:  chemical cues re-orient cells towards food or sites of infection, while physical cues report on local hydrostatic pressure, cellular crowding, adhesion etc. Together these cues allow a cell to make decisions about its differentiated fate (if it is in an embryonic state), move, divide, assemble into a tissue, commit apoptosis etc.  Understanding how cells integrate multiple  physico-chemical measurements before making a decision is thus critical in characterizing tissue and organ development, wound healing, cancer metastasis and in controlling cells to create artificial tissues and organs. This study  used a microfluidic environment to characterize this decision making process for a single cell that is faced with the task of multi-sensory integration. The quantitative model  developed have begun to synthesize aspects of hydrodynamics, elasticity,  statistical mechanics and   decision making for active matter systems such as a single cell.   The experiments and theory that result will thus have impact on a range of biological systems where mechanics, chemistry and decision making come together.
